clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of Exercise on Appetite Regulation in Overweight/Obese Individuals
clinical_study.official_title: The Effects of Exercise on Appetite Regulation in Overweight/Obese Individuals

brief_summary.textblock: In this study The Investigators are examining the effects of a 12-week exercise intervention on measures of appetite and food intake regulation in overweight to mildly obese healthy adults. The Investigators hypothesize that individuals who lose a significant amount of weight in response to the intervention will show a reduction in the brain response to food cues as measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) as compared to those who do not lose food. These changes in neuronal activity will be associated to physiologic and behavioral measures.

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Basic Science

primary_outcome.measure: fMRI response to visual food cues
primary_outcome.description: The neuronal response will be assessed by functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in response to visual food cues Blood oxygen dependent signal (BOLD) response in exposure to visual food cues will be measured during a fMRI scan and the difference between responses in those who lose weight vs. those who do not lose weight will be compared.
